prop.head.headtext: Legal Bases Used by the Courts for the Protection of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Criticism—Difficulty in Determining Questions of Liability

para.paratext: Gareth Jones, one of the leading commentators on the law of confidential information, cites what he states are two difficulties in determining liability if the property theory is invoked by the courts. One problem is the imposition of liability on a person who innocently exploits a secret:

No property theory can satisfactorily determine, even with the aid of equity, the question of the liability of the person who innocently exploits a secret. For example, there may be circumstances where it is just that a volunteer would be free of any liability to account for profits made through the use of confidential information.[1]

The second problem involves the liability of third parties who are strangers to the confidential relationship. Gareth Jones states that, in the case of confidential business information, “the defendant and others claiming from, through, or under him shall not knowingly take unfair advantage of the plaintiff's confidence”. There is an obligation to act in good faith. Unconscionable conduct is to be deterred. “The fact that a plaintiff may obtain relief against third parties who acquire such information is not a manifestation of a proprietary interest in confidential information but merely of an equitable good faith doctrine.”[2] Finally, Jones argues that even if the belief of the defendant is reasonable at the time the information is acquired, as soon as the defendant discovers that the information is confidential, he or she has an equitable obligation to the plaintiff. This would be so even if the defendant were a bona fide purchaser for value without notice. It has been argued, however, that only the property theory satisfactorily determines the question of the liability of the person who innocently exploits a secret. All other theories lead to the conclusion that there is no liability, which is contrary to the findings in many of the cases.[3]

In Seager v. Copydex Ltd.,[4] for example, the plaintiff was negotiating with the defendant to manufacture and distribute his invention to improve carpet grip. Without being requested by the defendant, he disclosed the details of his invention in the course of negotiations. After the negotiations had failed, the defendant began manufacturing a carpet grip similar to the plaintiff's. The plaintiff was awarded damages for breach of confidence. It was held on appeal that:

The law on this subject does not depend on any implied contract. It depends on the broad principle of equity that he who has received information in confidence shall not take unfair advantage of it. He must not make use of it to the prejudice of him who gave it without obtaining his consent.

This ruling was given even though there was no evidence of any conscious plagiarism of the plaintiff's invention. The plaintiff simply provided the defendant with the germ of an idea which, over a prolonged period, the defendant developed. More importantly, the Court of Appeal expressly held that the defendant company and its officers had not acted in bad faith.

Similarly, in Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd.,[5] Harris J. held that an employee of a television station had subconsciously drawn upon the memory of what he had been told by the plaintiff, although the defendant's employee honestly thought the idea was his own. Harris J. concluded, on the basis of this finding, that the television company should be restrained from making use of the idea which was originally imparted by the plaintiff in confidence.
Neither of these two cases can be explained using the equitable doctrine of good faith, as, in both cases, there was no evidence of bad faith on the part of the defendant.
In Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd.,[6] Megarry J. attempted to resolve the problem by applying the common law reasonable man test to the equitable doctrine of good faith:

It seems to me that if the circumstances are such that any reasonable man standing in the shoes of the recipient of the information would have realized that upon reasonable grounds the information was given to him in confidence, then this should suffice to impose upon him the equitable obligation of confidence.

The reasonable man test is problematic where a defendant acts honestly but unreasonably and gives consideration before discovering that the information is in fact confidential.[7] The “reasonable man” test provides that if the defendant's belief was unreasonable, the fact that the defendant was acting in good faith will not absolve the defendant of liability. M. Neave and M. Weinberg in their article, “The Nature and Function of Equities (Part II)”,[8] submitted that:

… it would be unprecedented for equity to require a defendant who had acted in good faith to restore lost benefits to a plaintiff unless a proprietary interest of the plaintiff had been infringed … Occasionally the defendant will be described as a “fiduciary” but this label merely conceals the fact that a constructive trust is deemed to exist, and the plaintiff is treated as the equitable owner of the property.

Occasionally the defendant will be described as a “fiduciary”, but this label merely conceals the fact that the plaintiff is in fact treated as the equitable owner of the property. Thus, the claim for protection of confidential business information is a proprietary action based on an equitable and not a legal interest in the information.[9]

Furthermore, the courts have often held that a bona fide purchaser for value without notice will acquire confidential business information free from any claim that the plaintiff might have.[10] The English Law Commission[11] has concluded that the defence of bona fide purchaser ought to operate in this area. It expressly rejected the “change of circumstances” criterion. The American Restatement of the Law of Torts also supports the view that the defence of bona fide purchaser ought to prevail in actions for breach of confidence.[12]

In view of what has just been stated, there is strong reason to believe that there is a property right in confidential business information, but that the plaintiff ought to have no rights against a defendant who is a bona fide purchaser, for value, of the confidential information. The plaintiff's right should only be against the party that wrongfully imparted the confidential information to the defendant. As one commentator stated, the courts:

… have acted so as to create a proprietary interest, but which has not yet reached the stage when it can be said to a plaintiff “bring yourself within that category and you will be protected”. Instead, all that can be said is that the remedies are available for protection. Prove that yours is a situation where they should be employed. But this does not mean that the “interest” once recognized as an equity is any the less a proprietary interest of a sort.[13]
